repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Closes #4763. When `!CYTHON_PEP489_MULTI_PHASE_INIT`, the module setup code sets `__path__` and `__file__` via calls to `importlib.find_loader`. That was deprecated in favor of `find_spec` in python 3.4. The deprecation warning is causing problems when running with `-Werror`. This PR
- uses the eqivalent of `package_path = [importlib.util.find_spec(module_name, package).origin.rsplit(os.sep, 1)[0]]`
- if `package` exists (`module_name` is a sub-package), prefix `'.'` to module_name

I tested this with `pypy3.8 runtests.py --no-cpp -vv`

It would be nice to backport this to the next 0.29 release if possible.

comment_data.body:
We normally try to make the Cython output as version independent as possible. Is there a way that this could be handled in C instead?

It looks like `module_name` is only used in the 3.4+ case, so you could just always do it?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3255,8 +3255,11 @@ def generate_module_import_setup(self, env, code):
             # out the module path at runtime by rerunning the import lookup
             code.putln("if (!CYTHON_PEP489_MULTI_PHASE_INIT) {")
             package_name, _ = self.full_module_name.rsplit('.', 1)
+            module_name = env.module_name
             if '.' in package_name:
                 parent_name = '"%s"' % (package_name.rsplit('.', 1)[0],)
+                if sys.version_info > (3, 4):

comment_data.body: `>=`? I think the function was added in 3.4
`module_name` is used in both paths, see line 453 which remained unchanged. I could change the C code to prefix a '.' to the `PyUnicodeObject` in the 3.4+ code path, but that also feels wrong.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3255,8 +3255,11 @@ def generate_module_import_setup(self, env, code):
             # out the module path at runtime by rerunning the import lookup
             code.putln("if (!CYTHON_PEP489_MULTI_PHASE_INIT) {")
             package_name, _ = self.full_module_name.rsplit('.', 1)
+            module_name = env.module_name
             if '.' in package_name:
                 parent_name = '"%s"' % (package_name.rsplit('.', 1)[0],)
+                if sys.version_info > (3, 4):

comment_data.body: I think this'll be blocking ` build.cythonize_script_package` - these are blocked if it matches part of it, rather than matches all of it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,7 +1,6 @@
 # Specific bugs that only apply to pypy2
 
 build.cythonize_script

@@ -1,7 +1,6 @@
 # Specific bugs that only apply to pypy2
 
 build.cythonize_script

comment_data.body: I changed this to always prepend a '.' if the module is a subpackage, and added C code to trim the '.' off for pypy3 < 3.4
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3255,8 +3255,11 @@ def generate_module_import_setup(self, env, code):
             # out the module path at runtime by rerunning the import lookup
             code.putln("if (!CYTHON_PEP489_MULTI_PHASE_INIT) {")
             package_name, _ = self.full_module_name.rsplit('.', 1)
+            module_name = env.module_name
             if '.' in package_name:
                 parent_name = '"%s"' % (package_name.rsplit('.', 1)[0],)
+                if sys.version_info > (3, 4):

commit.message: move from deprecated find_loader to find_spec

title: move from deprecated find_loader to find_spec
